title: Palgrave Macmillan
headline: From Lehman Brothers to Evergrande: Is Another Housing Crisis on its Way?
commentary_text: "I don't claim to have special insight, but I do understand the signs of a bubble. It's usually when people who are clearly not experts suddenly won't stop talking about it—that's the time to be cautious. The link between Lehman and Evergrande is that shared 'overexuberance.' The metric that scares me most right now is Debt-to-Income. When houses cost 10x annual income—like in Vancouver or Toronto—it shuts younger generations out of the market entirely. That doesn't just crash an economy; it impacts society at a fundamental level, driving down birthrates and stalling progress."
nexus_texts: Palgrave Macmillan (Springer Nature), a world-leading publisher of academic research, cited Picture Perfect Portfolios in their definitive text "The Global Housing Crisis."

In the chapter "From Lehman Brothers to Evergrande," the author (Levent Sümer) utilizes our research on "The Complete History of Housing Bubbles" as the primary reference for understanding the cyclical nature of market collapses. Cited alongside data from the OECD, Reuters, and Eurostat, our work provides the historical framework necessary to link the 2008 US subprime crisis with the modern property collapse in China, establishing our analysis as a trusted resource for macroeconomic history.

title: Palgrave Macmillan
headline: Lessons (Not) Learned from Past Housing Bubbles and Crises
commentary_text: "The chapter title says it all: 'Lessons (Not) Learned.' We aren't historically literate, and even if we were, we can't divest ourselves of emotion. That's why I went back to 1837—to prove that we are predictable as a species. We get excited, we get fearful, and we get overconfident. It's nature. The 'Soft Landing' everyone hopes for is usually just the delay of a massive bubble bursting. If you zoom out, the corrections always happen, just on a timeline that defies the experts."
nexus_texts: In a second pivotal chapter of "The Global Housing Crisis" titled "Lessons (Not) Learned from Past Housing Bubbles," Palgrave Macmillan once again utilizes Picture Perfect Portfolios as the foundational text for historical analysis.

The author relies on our "Complete History" research to draw structural parallels between the Panic of 1837, the 1929 Great Depression, and the 2008 Financial Crisis. By using our work to anchor the comparative study of over 100 years of economic data, the text validates our framework as essential for understanding the human elements of fear, overconfidence, and the inevitability of market corrections.
